desc:
# How to formulate knowledge Anki deck. (CrowdAnki JSON)
This deck is based on the article by Piotr Wozniak. You can find it here: https://www.supermemo.com/en/articles/20rules

It was originally created by some person from LessWrong community.

In order to use this deck and to contribute back - please use the CrowdAnki plugin: https://github.com/Stvad/CrowdAnki

You're welcome to use and improve this deck!

Deck Github repo: https://github.com/Stvad/Learning__How-to-Formulate-Knowledge
name: Learning::How-to-Formulate-Knowledge

note_models.name: Basic [optional reversed, extra, source]
Cloze [extra, source]

fields: my speed of learning depends on what?
how I formulate the material determines what?
the same material can be learned {{c1::many times faster}} if well formulated
the 20 rules for formulating knowledge are listed in what order?
this deck is based on what article?
who wrote The 20 Rules of Formulating Knowledge?
do not {{c2::learn}} if I do not {{c1::understand}}
learning a German history book word for word is an example of what?
learning what you do not understand
before anything else, always {{c1::understand}} the material!
learning items I do not understand will do what?
the time needed for what is astronomical?

"blind learning"
(learning what you do not understand)
build a picture of the whole before doing what?
breaking it down into simple items
before breaking an item down into simpler items, what should I do?
build a picture of the whole
if the whole shows holes, I should...
do not start with {{c1::memorizing}} loosely related facts
do not start with memorizing what?
what should I do instead of memorizing loosely related facts?
read something that puts them together
a simpler picture of the learned whole is what?
what type of picture of the whole is better?
simpler models are easier to [... and ...]
simpler models are easier to comprehend and encompass
what can you always do with simple models?
how much of my time do the basics take?
is memorizing obvious things a waste of time?
how much time do I ususally spend repeating 3-5% of the material?
I usually spend 50% of my time repeated how much of the material?
a memory lapse on the basics is...
formulated material must be as {{c1::simple}} as possible.

1. losing information
2. skipping the difficult parts
two reasons knowledge must be simple
simplicity is easier for the brain because you...
always process the idea in the same way
in my brain, remembering an idea is like what?
the labyrinth in our minds is easiest to navigate when an idea is what?
what should always be as short as possible?
the longer it takes to {{c2::remember}} an idea, the {{c1::simpler}} it needs to be
how do I ideally want my brain to work each repetition
I want my brain to work exactly the same way each...
what should I do if simplifying isn't working?

Rules 1-5
1. {{c1::Understand}}
2. {{c2::Start with the Big Picture}}
3. {{c3::Build on the Basics}}
4. {{c4::Simplify}}
5. {{c5::Use Cloze Deletion}}
this very card is an {{c1::example}} of {{c2::cloze deletion}}
what does cloze deletion greatly speed up?
is cloze deletion recommended for beginners?
is close deletion effective for experienced learners?
what do they say about pictures?
a picture is worth a thousand words
images of information are usually far less {{c1::volatile}} than words
what is a problem with using imagery?
they can be time-consuming to make
two common examples of mnemonic techniques?
peg lists and mind maps are examples of what?
is graphic deletion as good as cloze deletion?
what is great for learning things like anatomy and geography?
how hard is it to memorize a set?
"apple, pear, peach" is an example of what?
"What countries belong to the EU?" is an example of what?
if a set is unavoidable, what should you do with it?
which is better: enumerations or sets?
in general, what should I do with sets?

Rules 6-10
6. {{c1::Use Imagery}}
7. {{c2::Use Mnemonic Techniques}}
8. {{c3::Use Graphic Deletion}}
9. {{c4::Avoid Sets}}
10. {{c5::Avoid Enumeration}}
listing the countries in the EU alphabetically is an example of what?
the way the 20 rules are presented in this deck is an example of what?
how easy are enumerations to memorize?
what should I do with enumerations?
if enumerations are necessary, what should I use on them?
what style of cloze deletion should be used with enumerations?
what easily happens when I learn about similar things?
when knowledge of one item makes it hard to remember another item
"when knowledge of one item makes it hard to remember another item"
confusing the meanings of historic and historical is an example of what?
what is the single greatest cause of forgetting?
what is the solution to interference? (2 parts)
to combat interference, make items as...
make items as unambiguous as possible to do what?
the moment I spot interference, I should what?
"I know the meanings of inept and inapt, but I'm confusing the two" is an example of what?
conveying an idea in as few words as necessary

replacing
"Aldus invented desktop publishing with PageMaker but failed to improve. It was soon outdistanced by "
with
"PageMaker lost ground to "
is an example of what?
{{c1::Referring to other memories}} involves using things you {{c2::already know}} to simplify cards

replacing
"shamelessly conscious of one's failings and asking in a begging way"
with
"shamelessly humble and supplicant"
is an example of what?
greatly enhance memories by linking them to what? (2 things)
"What is the name of a soft bed without arms or back? (like the one at Robert's parents)" is an example of what?
personalized examples are very resistant to interference
I have thousands of {{c2::personal experiences}} on which I can build other {{c1::memories}}.

Rules 11-15
11. {{c1::Combat Interference}}
12. {{c2::Optimize Wording}}
13. {{c3::Refer to Other Memories}}
14. {{c4::Use Personalized Examples}}
15. {{c5::Rely on Emotional States}}
why are vivid and shocking examples valuable?
illustrate with examples that are [... or ...]
illustrate with examples that are vivid or shocking
context cues put ideas within a {{c1::category}}
what puts ideas within a category?
"title:, author:, date:, math:, biochem:, etc" are examples of...
what does it mean to have redundancy?
does redundancy contradict the simplify principle?
redundancy can be performed by repeating information using...
what do sources help to distinguish?
what do sources help to judge about an idea? (2 things)
sources may not be necessary for what types of knowledge? (2 types)
date stamping means including the date the information was [... or ...]
date stamping means including the date the information was created or retrieved
when is date stamping particularly useful?
volatile knowledge is knowledge that is...

Rules 16-20
16. {{c1::Use Context Cues}}
17. {{c2::Use Redundancy}}
18. {{c3::Provide Sources}}
19. {{c4::Provide Date Stamping}}
20. {{c5::Prioritize}}
what should I do rather than memorize whole books?
putting less important information in parentheses helps to what?

prioritize
(put some less important information here)
what helps me deal with sources that vary in quality?
what does it make sense to do, other than memorizing whole books?
